â€œThe Testamentsâ€ by Margaret Atwood offers a new perspective on the Republic of Gilead, among the perspective of the world outside Gilead.

The world of Gilead is presented from the perspective of Aunt Lydia, one of the founding figures of Gilead, who is trying to bring into attention the crimes of Commander Judd, along with other crimes. She is trying to do this, because things have got out of hand and everything needs to be stopped.

Daisy and Agnes are the ones that bring outside Gilead the proof of all those crimes, and the ones that helped with Gileadâ€™s faith.

This book offered an ending to â€œThe Handmaidâ€™s Taleâ€ and despite the fact that some things were confusing at first, it was an interesting book to read due to the dual perspective it offered.

The Testaments by Margaret Atwood

I have mixed thoughts about this book. Overall, on the surface, I liked it. It enraged me, but reading it in our current environment, of course it did lol. Perhaps this wasn't my smartest reading choice.

Thinking about it a bit more, I have some issues. I find Daisy wildly unlikable (which is fine, I guess) and stupidly stubborn (which is problematic). I just struggle to see someone acting the way she did in the situation she was in. And Aunt Lydia. Given her background, I struggle to believe she could have done the things we all know she's done. Embracing Gilead and maneuvering to be in a position of power, sure. That's survival. But that doesn't explain the extent to which we all know she went. And then to do what she did here... I dunno.

Overall, it was an enjoyable read (lol if you can call it that), but I found it a bit wanting.
